awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CBET: The role of sunlight in determining the fate and microbial impact of microplastics in surface waters
awd_abstract_narration:
Microplastics are plastic particles smaller than 5 mm in size. Microplastics mostly originate from fragmentation of larger plastic objects and are now found globally from drinking water to rivers, lakes and streams, and the oceans. An estimated 8 million tonnes of plastic waste enter the oceans from land each year, yet only a fraction of this material is accounted for by floating microplastics. One hypothesis for the missing microplastic is that exposure to sunlight degrades them to dissolved carbon. This project will assess whether sunlight-driven photochemical reactions release dissolved organic carbon from plastics, resulting in removal of the plastics from the water. A second objective of this project will test whether the chemicals released affect bacterial growth and survivability in natural waters. Results will improve our understanding of the fate of floating plastics in natural waters. This project will have significant broader impacts in the fields of environmental microbiology and photochemistry. Results will be incorporated into high school classroom learning geared towards middle and high school students, to increase the Nation's scientific literacy and educate the next generation of environmental engineers and scientists. In addition, the results will inform society on how to prioritize plastic waste management to protect human and ecological health. 

Microplastics are plastic particles smaller than 5 mm in size and originate from fragmentation of larger plastic objects released to the environment. Microplastics are found globally from drinking water to rivers, lakes and streams, and the oceans, where more than 98% of all buoyant microplastics are unaccounted for in loading estimates. The hypothesis for this research is that sunlight is responsible for degrading floating microplastics to dissolved organic carbon (DOC) on relatively short time scales (years). This hypothesis will be tested through a series of field, experimental, and analytical studies. The second hypothesis is that DOC released from photochemical breakdown will impact microbial growth. This hypothesis will be tested through bioassays with natural marine and freshwater microbes to assess the degradation kinetics (dissolution, fragmentation, and oxidation) of microplastics in seawater and freshwater in the light and dark, and with and without microbes. Experiments with plastics of variable polymer chemistry, size, and previous oxidation history will reveal the role of these factors in explaining variability in degradation rates to inform future modeling studies of plastic loss. The project brings together scientists with complementary educational, field, experimental, and analytical skills to transform our understanding of the fate and impact of buoyant microplastics in surface waters. Results will be disseminated to other scientists, the press, and incorporated into high school classroom learning via publication in the Science Journal for Kids, an open access journal which adapts primary, peer-reviewed research papers with age-appropriate language and illustrations geared towards middle and high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microplastics, plastic particles smaller than 5 mm in size, are now found in nearly all natural and managed waters, from drinking water to rivers, lakes and streams, and the oceans. An estimated 8 million tonnes of plastic waste enter the oceans from land each year, yet only a fraction of this material is accounted for by floating microplastics. One hypothesis for the “missing plastics” is that exposure to sunlight dissolves them. We tested this hypothesis, demonstrating through a number of laboratory studies that sunlight does dissolve plastics at the sea surface. We showed that the main quantified product formed as plastics dissolve is dissolved organic carbon (DOC).  We advanced knowledge of the kinetics and rates of plastic losses in sunlight, demonstrating that larger microplastics (~1 to 5 mm) can be removed from surface waters (i.e., completely dissolved by sunlight) in years to decades. We also chemically characterized the byproducts formed as plastics photochemically dissolve and showed that the chemicals released as plastics dissolve can be harmful to bacteria in natural waters. Results have improved our fundamental understanding of photochemical dissolution of plastics upon exposure to sunlight, the fate of floating plastics in natural waters, the impacts of microplastics upon microorganisms, and also inform decisions about how to prioritize plastic waste management. Major research findings include:

 

1)     The photochemical removal of plastics from surface waters follows linear kinetics.

2)     The time taken to completely dissolve plastics at the water’s surface is impacted by polymer type (up to 10x difference in rates) and even more so by particle size. Nanoplastics can be removed in hours to days, while a 10 cm buoy would persist for hundreds of years before being completely dissolved.

3)     Although plastics are composed of chemically monotonous polymers, when they photo-dissolve they form a diverse suite of soluble organic byproducts.

4)     Byproducts formed as microplastics photodegrade can either stimulate or inhibit microbial growth, with unknown consequences for aquatic ecology.

 

Taken together, our work demonstrates that although plastics are often described as persistent, they do chemically degrade in sunlight. The rate of plastic loss is sufficient that if we were to stop plastics entering the ocean, buoyant microplastics would eventually dissolve. Although this is promising, there is no sign of plastic pollution declining. Furthermore, we show that the byproducts formed as plastics are removed can disrupt natural systems. That some of the byproducts formed are toxic to bacteria suggests they may also be toxic to other organisms, including humans.

 

This work supported: a postdoc, Lixin Zhu, who is now taking a faculty position in China; two PhD students, Erin Tuttle, who is now a tenure track Professor at Assumption University, and Andresa Lima, now in her 3rd year; and a MS student, Karina Ramos, who graduated and secured her desired job as a Project Manager at the Mystic Watershed Association. Undergraduate student Arianna Patterson was fully supported to take part in a SEA Semester and subsequent research Co-op. She continued to work with Stubbins until graduation. She is a co-author on two papers, has a first author paper in review at this time, and is currently applying to graduate school to continue to study plastics in the environment. Eight other undergraduate students were engaged in experiential laboratory work related to the project.

 

The PIs disseminated project goals and research outcomes to broad audiences, including high school, undergraduate, and graduate students; the scientific community outside of geosciences; environmental and other public groups; and policy experts and policy makers. This work provides evidence-based information useful to design actions to mitigate global plastic pollution.
